{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3540514,"name":"","username":"SleeplessCadder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9f8e36/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T00:50:11.980Z","cooked":"

On two sides of our robot, we have pocketed metal plates that make up the frame perimeter. One of our mentors expressed worry about this because they have not seen this be done before. We just wanted to check the legality of this just in case before our week 1 competition. Thanks for all that reply.

It is legal. Our team used a .25 inch plate for utb intake last year.

Just to make one or two things clear-ish:

Those pocketed plates define the Robot Perimeter. So if there’s any sort of gap restrictions between bumpers and perimeter (I don’t recall any this year), they’d apply to the frame behind them where the plates aren’t. If the Robot Perimeter is oversized because of those plates, prepare to get creative with how you reduce length.

Other than that, all legal and ready to play!

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T01:49:19.039Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":68.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":493245,"topic_slug":"is-it-legal-to-have-pocketed-1-8-plates-as-part-of-your-frame-perimeter","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-legal-to-have-pocketed-1-8-plates-as-part-of-your-frame-perimeter/493245/8","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3540722,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T03:42:22.574Z","cooked":"

There are no limits on gaps between bumper and frame this year. The plates would define ROBOT PERIMETER, and the bumper hard part zone and maximum thickness go from the ROBOT PERIMETER.

Remember to read the rule manual if there is no rule, you can do what you want. If you think you remember a rule in the past but can find it this year, check an old manual find the rule and check the same section in the current manual.
